I assume it would be similar to the -9 in terms of its commonality. And yet, it's higher-priced. How should we be thinking about that [indiscernible] production block?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. I think you hit it, Peter. That's exactly the way to think about it. On the commonality side, as you know, that was a key factor as we've developed that airplane, to get it into production system and get the commonality to the -9. And we're wel
componenttext: Yes -- no. I think you hit it, Peter. That's exactly the way to think about it. On the commonality side, as you know, that was a key factor as we've developed that airplane, to get it into production system and get the commonality to the -9. And we're well north of 95% with regards to commonality in the factory. So that's going extremely well. That will certainly help as we introduce that into production system and start ramping rate up on that. And that -- I'd say that's progressing well. And as you know, we'll start to deliver that airplane in 2018. So we're watching that progress through the system and going -- like I said, development has gone very well as is kind of early assembly and fabrication efforts. I think we're tracking well. But think of it just like you did, like you mentioned on the -9. Very smooth, deliberate introduction into that system and then get the rate up. [indiscernible] important part of the mix within the overall profile of the 787.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's on the existing final assembly lines and not on the [indiscernible] anymore?
componenttext: And that's on the existing final assembly lines and not on the [indiscernible] anymore?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we go to Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And next, we go to Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the defense side of the business. I wonder if you could talk about some of the opportunities there, particularly on the fighter side. There's been some news about potential orders for Kuwait and -- for Qatar and the potential start of F-18 line in Indi
componenttext: On the defense side of the business. I wonder if you could talk about some of the opportunities there, particularly on the fighter side. There's been some news about potential orders for Kuwait and -- for Qatar and the potential start of F-18 line in Indian. And how are you thinking about the fighter franchise going forward? And whatever specificity can you provide about where -- if those orders for Kuwait and Qatar would have come through where sort of that will take production up on those programs in St. Louis?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, thanks for the question. When you take a look at our fighter lines, it's both domestic and international opportunities. I think it's important to note that, as you've seen in the fiscal year '17 budget deliberations here in the U.S., some strong sup
componenttext: Seth, thanks for the question. When you take a look at our fighter lines, it's both domestic and international opportunities. I think it's important to note that, as you've seen in the fiscal year '17 budget deliberations here in the U.S., some strong support from our U.S. Navy requesting additional F-18s for the domestic fleet. And we're hopeful that as part of the FY '17 budget deliberations, that there will be additional super Hornets included in the budget. I think, as you're aware, the U.S. Navy's requests, it's an unfunded request in the system for 14 additional aircraft plus 2 via OCO funding. So there are domestic opportunities and supporting our customer here in the U.S. To make sure that they have the right fighter fleets and capacity for the future, I think, is an important part of the equation. And we continue see strong support for the Super Hornet as well as modifications and upgrades to the F-15 Eagles. Internationally, as you alluded to, there are a number of opportunities and campaigns that are well underway. They are global, including opportunities in the Middle East. And while I can't comment on specific campaigns, I want to respect our customers process here, we do see opportunities in the Middle East. Press reports you've seen around Qatar and Kuwait are certainly 2 very important customers for us. Remember, those are all governed by the foreign military sales process and are government-to-government arrangements. We're supporting those, but we do see opportunities for both the F-18 and the F-15 internationally. Middle East, Asia Pacific, potential opportunities in Europe and Canada as well. And all of those give us some level of confidence that we'll be able to extend those fighter lines into the early 2020s. And that presents an opportunity for us that's important and one that we continue to pursue in that business space, gives us the capacity to invest in future product lines as well that leverage our St. Louis workforce. So we're encouraged by some of the progress there. But again, those international deals are really government-to-government arrangements, and we'll continue to support those appropriately.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Rob Spingarn with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Rob Spingarn with Credit Suisse.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I Wanted to follow up a little bit, Dennis, on what you Were talking about at the end of your monologue about playing offense and your greater attention to the lifecycle opportunity. So while it's clear that you see something for Boeing here, to what exte
componenttext: I Wanted to follow up a little bit, Dennis, on what you Were talking about at the end of your monologue about playing offense and your greater attention to the lifecycle opportunity. So while it's clear that you see something for Boeing here, to what extent is this effort being driven by the carriers? You did mention your customers, and it sounds like there's some thrust from them in this process.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Year. When we think about growing the services business, Rob, and then more broadly, lifecycle support, that starts with our customers because our objective here is to make sure that the airplanes we're delivering and the usage they're getting from those
componenttext: Year. When we think about growing the services business, Rob, and then more broadly, lifecycle support, that starts with our customers because our objective here is to make sure that the airplanes we're delivering and the usage they're getting from those airplanes is profitable and productive and reliable. And our business thrives on reliable and productive fleets for our customers, and it's true in both the commercial and defense business. And we believe that our OEM knowledge and depth of detail in the airplane design can add value throughout the entire life cycle. I think, as you're well aware, if you look at the installed commercial fleets, you could argue that we're about 50% of the installed fleet. Yet, if you look at our market share in terms of services today, we're about 6% to 7% market share and services. And I believe it's reasonable for a company like Boeing with the OEM depth and knowledge we have to have a larger share of the services market. And I think that's to the advantage of our customers. And part of the value equation that we're bringing to bear here is Boeing, with our supply chain, providing better capability, better efficiency, better profitability for our customers, it's adding value both for them and for Boeing. Those are the kind of business models we're pursuing.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dennis, I guess, the natural follow-on question here, is this a bit of a 0-sum game. We're talking a bit about a share shift toward Boeing. How do you manage that with your supply chain? Because if we're benefiting the airlines and Boeing is going to t
componenttext: So Dennis, I guess, the natural follow-on question here, is this a bit of a 0-sum game. We're talking a bit about a share shift toward Boeing. How do you manage that with your supply chain? Because if we're benefiting the airlines and Boeing is going to take a larger share, how do we do this without disrupting the supply chain?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, Rob, I don't see this as a zero-sum game. This is a growing marketplace that we're operating in. As we've mentioned previously, we look at what's happening in global growth of commercial traffic, our market outlook for the next 20 years, 38,000
componenttext: Actually, Rob, I don't see this as a zero-sum game. This is a growing marketplace that we're operating in. As we've mentioned previously, we look at what's happening in global growth of commercial traffic, our market outlook for the next 20 years, 38,000 new aircraft needed by our customers, growing passenger base. This is a growing market and one in which we expect to gain market share in a growing market. That's good for our customers, and it's done in partnership with our suppliers, with our supply chain. It can be good for them as well. Now there may be some sectors where we will take market share and where we can add value for our customers. We'll do that. But I'd prefer to look at this as a growing marketplace and one that the growth is accelerated when we provide efficient service. And when we can do that in partnership with our supply chain, it's good for all of industry and it can be good for our customers.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we're going to Doug Harned with Bernstein.
componenttext: Next, we're going to Doug Harned with Bernstein.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked about eventually getting to mid-teens margins at BCA, and that would be well above where you are right now. Could you talk about what needs to happen in terms of cost reduction and other initiatives to get there? And when should we see movem
componenttext: You've talked about eventually getting to mid-teens margins at BCA, and that would be well above where you are right now. Could you talk about what needs to happen in terms of cost reduction and other initiatives to get there? And when should we see movement in that direction? And what's the approximate timing for reaching a mid-teens-type goal?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Doug, let me give you a top-of-mind answer, and I'll let Greg to augment that. I'm working very closely with Ray and his team on this. We're all aligned on where we're trying to take the business and grow both top and bottom line in BCA. And as you h
componenttext: Yes. Doug, let me give you a top-of-mind answer, and I'll let Greg to augment that. I'm working very closely with Ray and his team on this. We're all aligned on where we're trying to take the business and grow both top and bottom line in BCA. And as you heard our margin performance year-to-date with a couple of the headwinds that we're dealing with in terms of R&D investments this year and mix. But if I look ahead to next year, we are pushing towards returning to double-digit margins in our commercial airplane business next year. And when we look at that mid-teens margin, the more aspirational target, this is something that we intend to focus on here over the next several years as we head towards the end of the decade. So this is within our planning view. This is not some aspirational target that's out beyond what we envisioned for the business. This is part of our planning effort. And driving that level of productivity and performance is important because it creates the capacity to invest in the future and it creates shareholder value. And we intend to accomplish all of those objectives. Sub elements of that include the strategy that you've seen us lay out. This is why we're working with our supply chain on Partnering for Success to drive bottom line performance. It's our lean initiative, our Capturing the Value of Quality effort, market-based affordability, and frankly, just a relentless pursuit of productivity. That's good business. It's the right way to run the business, and we are committed to that path. And that's a path that allows us to compete and win. It allows us to invest in innovation, and it allows us to return value to shareholders. And Greg, you want to add in something?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you hit -- hit all the big levers on the things we were focused on. Certainly, there's level of maturity of each of those of where we are, but I would say the focus in each one of those categories, including the services that we just talked a
componenttext: Yes, I think you hit -- hit all the big levers on the things we were focused on. Certainly, there's level of maturity of each of those of where we are, but I would say the focus in each one of those categories, including the services that we just talked about with Rob, as well as the development efforts to try and become more efficient and leveraging the enterprise around development efforts, those are all the major categories that I'd say are led by Dennis ultimately, but then by each one of us, to try to look for more efficient ways to execute on those activities. But as I've said before, I would kind of view it as no rock has been left unturned. It is an objective. It's an aspiration. But as you know, it's happening within our own business today. And that certainly gives us a clear understanding of the art of the possible here. And I think what Dennis said, it's competing to win. It's investing in our future and ultimately driving value for our shareholders and all of our stakeholders. So we're going to continue on this path. We're going to talk about a little bit more the investor conference here coming up. But it's a very consistent, I'll say, and a high-priority task for all of us on the team.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I also want to recognize Ray's and Lian's efforts on the business level. We are all aligned on objectives here and working this as an enterprise team. And Ray and Leanne have really been driving this at the business level, and I just want to acknowle
componenttext: Yes. I also want to recognize Ray's and Lian's efforts on the business level. We are all aligned on objectives here and working this as an enterprise team. And Ray and Leanne have really been driving this at the business level, and I just want to acknowledge the great work that they're doing.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you say that this is really a steady progression that you envision toward the aspiration as opposed to something where you see a turning point in the 3 years ahead? Or is this something that we should see progress on sort of on a year-to-year basi
componenttext: And can you say that this is really a steady progression that you envision toward the aspiration as opposed to something where you see a turning point in the 3 years ahead? Or is this something that we should see progress on sort of on a year-to-year basis?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You got it, Doug. Characterizing it as steady progression is exactly the way I'd look at it. And just as we said, we expect the opportunity at of us, with the backlog we have and the long view that gives us and the production ramp-up ahead of us in Commer
componenttext: You got it, Doug. Characterizing it as steady progression is exactly the way I'd look at it. And just as we said, we expect the opportunity at of us, with the backlog we have and the long view that gives us and the production ramp-up ahead of us in Commercial Airplanes headed to well north of 900 aircraft a year, we have the opportunity, both top and bottom line, to create the steady progression. And it's revenue growth, it's cash growth and it's margin and earnings growth. And that is our plan.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to stick with the profitability quickly. Greg, can you just clarify. If you were to look in BCA period expenses, excluding R&D in the quarter, was there any big variance versus last year? And maybe speak to any change in the cadence over the course
componenttext: I want to stick with the profitability quickly. Greg, can you just clarify. If you were to look in BCA period expenses, excluding R&D in the quarter, was there any big variance versus last year? And maybe speak to any change in the cadence over the course of this year? Because I know that can weigh on the margins. And then secondly, I wondered if you might hit on the Universe's program differences. I mean $28 million, that's the smallest since before you began delivering the 787. But's I'll assume given where the deferred productions been running that the 8 7 was still a pretty big number there. That implies that you had some negative differences elsewhere. Was that 737 customer mix? Or 777? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you got it. It's mix. It's narrowbody mix within the quarter. That's really the biggest driver there, Carter.
componenttext: Yes, you got it. It's mix. It's narrowbody mix within the quarter. That's really the biggest driver there, Carter.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you have a couple of 100 million up around 8 7 and a couple of 100 million down on the narrowbody?
componenttext: So you have a couple of 100 million up around 8 7 and a couple of 100 million down on the narrowbody?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Little bit less than that on the 8 7.
componenttext: Yes. Little bit less than that on the 8 7.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the period expenses?
componenttext: And on the period expenses?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not a big difference. I mean relatively flat.The margin for the quarter, what you said. There's a mix in the quarter. A little bit on escalation and higher R&D, as we said, as ramping up the 777X. So as I look at the next 3 quarters ahead, we'll ha
componenttext:
Yes. Not a big difference. I mean relatively flat.
The margin for the quarter, what you said. There's a mix in the quarter. A little bit on escalation and higher R&D, as we said, as ramping up the 777X. So as I look at the next 3 quarters ahead, we'll have more favorable mix in there, and the R&D profile will be a little bit different. So that's how we see the path to the guidance for the balance of the year.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then on that 3 7 margin comment you made with the block extension, that's net of the escalation adjustment you extended the block and had a favorable?
componenttext: Then on that 3 7 margin comment you made with the block extension, that's net of the escalation adjustment you extended the block and had a favorable?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Next, we go to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dennis, do you still feel good about achieving the book-to-bill about 1 this year? And if you were to provide a color on what sort of mix you might be sitting -- I know you guys mentioned, I think, you said 40 to 50 777 orders annually. Obviously, a littl
componenttext: Dennis, do you still feel good about achieving the book-to-bill about 1 this year? And if you were to provide a color on what sort of mix you might be sitting -- I know you guys mentioned, I think, you said 40 to 50 777 orders annually. Obviously, a little change in 46 [ph] find that's not surprising obviously. But how should we think about the [indiscernible] in terms of the mix of 777 orders this year and beyond and then of course, the book-to-bill question?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet. On the overall book-to-bill, yes, once again this year, we're anticipating a book-to-bill of about 1, so similar to last year. As you know, timing of orders is a little hard to predict. But generally, we'll look at order volume and energy in the
componenttext: You bet. On the overall book-to-bill, yes, once again this year, we're anticipating a book-to-bill of about 1, so similar to last year. As you know, timing of orders is a little hard to predict. But generally, we'll look at order volume and energy in the marketplace, we'd say book-to-bill of about 1. And continuing healthy opportunities around the globe. Most of that, again driven by passenger growth and the replacement demand from our customers, lesser of that driven by cargo. As I've mentioned earlier, the cargo market remains flattish. The prominent demand there is in the narrowbody arena. So 737 sales opportunities for the MAX remain very robust globally. Widebody demand, not as hot as narrowbody demand, but still strong, especially in areas where it's driven by passenger growth, middle East and Asia Pacific in particular. We're seeing that and continuing solid orders volume for 787 and for the 777. And as I said, on 777, current generation, we're targeting 40 to 50 sales a year to fill the bridge. We still have work to go, but we've completed 11 -- or successfully sold 11 so far this year. So roughly on track. But we still have some work to do to remain -- to fill the remainder of the bridge. We have about a dozen or so very significant campaigns underway for the 777. So while we have work to do, we also see the opportunity to complete filling of that bridge. On the other side of the bridge, the 777X remains in a very strong market-differentiated place. And if we look out the future on widebodies, between 787 and 777X in particular, we feel very strong about the product lineup that we have. So overall, healthy, steady market demand. Book-to-bill of about 1 this year, heavily weighted to the narrowbody side, but seeing reasonable demand in both narrows and widebodies.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll go to Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- Dennis, you've done -- actually, should actually push Greg on this. You take a $0.24 charge, and you don't change guidance. So something else must have worked out a little bit better as you go and look for the year. But I also want to ask, Dennis a
componenttext: The -- Dennis, you've done -- actually, should actually push Greg on this. You take a $0.24 charge, and you don't change guidance. So something else must have worked out a little bit better as you go and look for the year. But I also want to ask, Dennis about the KC-46 for a moment. You still have a couple of milestones to complete. For example, C-17, and it appears as if the offer to the customer has been pushed a little bit to the right. So could you talk a little bit about what you're doing? A lot of money on this program and a lot of time and effort, but it's still proving to be a little bit more challenging than you addressed. So can you talk about what you've done to change it so that you put the nail on this thing so that it doesn't bite you anymore?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet. You bet. Howard, good questions. And just first of all on your overall margin question, Greg, I look back there to back in the tanker comment on that. But you saw in the first quarter that we did take the $0.24 charge on tanker, we're able to off
componenttext: You bet. You bet. Howard, good questions. And just first of all on your overall margin question, Greg, I look back there to back in the tanker comment on that. But you saw in the first quarter that we did take the $0.24 charge on tanker, we're able to offset a majority of that with just good solid performance. And Greg can walk you through some offsets there. But one of the reasons that we've reaffirmed our year-end guidance is that the first quarter performance that we've seen broadly across the enterprise, some of the work we're doing to drive productivity that I talked about earlier and our plans for the rest of the year, give us confidence that we'll overcome that $0.24 charge. And that's part of the reasons for holding our year-end guidance. And I'll let Greg comment more on that later. But specifically, the tanker, you're right. A lot of focus in that, and I can tell you that we have raised the level of enterprise focus on executing on delivering on the program. We -- as you've seen, we've made some personnel changes to provide some additional oversight and emphasis on the program. Liane, step into our new role as playing a strong role there along with Scott Fancher and teaming up with Ran and came in the commercial airplane side. So we've got the right people in the program. [indiscernible] completing milestone C testing, the production approval position. We are about 80% complete on the flight testing that's required for milestone C. And we are moving towards completion of that milestone and approval around the end of the second quarter. Again, subject to the normal U.S. government process. The next major milestone beyond that will be delivery of the first 18 [ph] tankers, and we remain on schedule to do that August of 2017. And you're right, we have invested some money to hold that schedule. We think it's the right thing to do. It delivers on our customer commitments. It delivers on an important program, and we're committed to hitting that schedule. And it allows us to accelerate our movement into the production program. Ultimately, we still see this in the long run as a franchise program, a market of around 400 aircraft and one that will produce profitable growth for decades to come both in terms of production and support to our customers. So without question, this is an investment worth making. While we don't like taking a charge, we're confident that we're doing the right things here. We've got the right people on it. We are now in the final stages of the development program. And to your point about putting a nail in it, we are not now discovering new technical issues. Frankly, this is about the fact that we are concurrently finishing up development and ramping up production. We've got the first 7 production aircraft flowing through our Everett factory now in our supply chain [indiscernible] out to airplane #15. So see concurrency cost. So that is an intentional investment we're making to keep the program on schedule. We're closing in on it. We're not done yet. We're going to be very focused on getting to the finish line, but I'm confident we'll get there and also confident of its is going to be a great program for our customers and our company for decades to come. Greg, you want to provide any other color on...

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean -- I think you hit the high points, Dennis. Yes. Certainly, Howard, the balance of year just got more challenging. And we got a path forward to meet to guide. Even taking that into consideration between accelerating our productivity efforts and foc
componenttext: I mean -- I think you hit the high points, Dennis. Yes. Certainly, Howard, the balance of year just got more challenging. And we got a path forward to meet to guide. Even taking that into consideration between accelerating our productivity efforts and focusing in the area to be sure that, and committed to doing that. So we'll keep marching ahead as quarter by quarter to make sure we achieved what we put out there.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will be from George Shapiro which Shapiro Research.
componenttext: And that will be from George Shapiro which Shapiro Research.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. a 2-part question. One, Greg, with R&D, it was a little higher this quarter than I thought of. But if I just annualized that, you'll get about where your expectations. So do I assume that R&D is relatively flat in subsequent quarters? And then for De
componenttext: Yes. a 2-part question. One, Greg, with R&D, it was a little higher this quarter than I thought of. But if I just annualized that, you'll get about where your expectations. So do I assume that R&D is relatively flat in subsequent quarters? And then for Dennis, if you could just provide some color on some of the articles we've been seeing about potentially coming up with a different 3 7 derivatives to stave off [indiscernible] series as to what the status of that might be?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the R&D, George, that's about right. I mean, there's obviously some moving pieces in there as 777X starts to ramp up and -10 profile turns down around with MAX. But generally, quarter by quarter, you're going to look at kind of a similar trend right no
componenttext: On the R&D, George, that's about right. I mean, there's obviously some moving pieces in there as 777X starts to ramp up and -10 profile turns down around with MAX. But generally, quarter by quarter, you're going to look at kind of a similar trend right now.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And George, on your question about the 737 family. Yes, we continue to have a very good dialogue with our customers about their future needs. As you know, the MAX 8 is now [indiscernible] production system. We've got 3 aircraft in flight test. That airpla
componenttext: And George, on your question about the 737 family. Yes, we continue to have a very good dialogue with our customers about their future needs. As you know, the MAX 8 is now [indiscernible] production system. We've got 3 aircraft in flight test. That airplane is looking very good. And we're confident that's going to add a lot of value for our customers. We're continuing to see strong sales of the MAX family overall. As we take a look at the MAX7, sort of the lower seat end of that family of aircraft, that is an area where we're having active discussions with our customers. It's too early to give any specific details or decisions, but I think it's worth saying that, that airplane is viewed very favorably by our customers. We have a very clear value proposition that will add value and operating cost reduction for them. And we also have the flexibility to design it to meet their needs. So we'll continue those discussions. And as we reach decision points, we'll make sure to make everybody aware but remain very confident on the MAX introduction, the transition and the value it will add to our customers.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that completes the analysts question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'll now return you to The Boeing company for introductory remarks by Mr. Tom Downey, Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications. Mr. Downey, please go ahead.

componenttext: Thank you. We will continue with questions for Dennis and Greg. If you have any questions following this part of the session, please call our media relations team at (312) 544-2002. [Operator Instructions]

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg.
componenttext: And we'll go to Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on some of the earlier questions about productivity initiatives. I'm wondering if you can sort of give us a target for our company-wide headcount, changes or reductions. And also I know 4,000 jobs at BCA is a lot, but -- I mean, these are
componenttext: Just a follow-up on some of the earlier questions about productivity initiatives. I'm wondering if you can sort of give us a target for our company-wide headcount, changes or reductions. And also I know 4,000 jobs at BCA is a lot, but -- I mean, these are job reductions coming through attrition and voluntary layoffs. And I'm wondering, frankly, if that's going to get the job done or if more meaningful restructuring is needed, especially given your margin goals for the unit.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julie. Let me give you a little context around this. Because when we pursue productivity and cost competitiveness, we look at all categories of costs. So certainly, direct labor cost, headcount is one of those. But there are many other factors. In fa
componenttext: Yes, Julie. Let me give you a little context around this. Because when we pursue productivity and cost competitiveness, we look at all categories of costs. So certainly, direct labor cost, headcount is one of those. But there are many other factors. In fact, other factors that are larger than direct headcount. Indirect costs, overhead, infrastructure, facilities, supply chain. Just as a reminder, a good portion of our cost is outside of Boeing. So that's where our Partnering for Success initiative comes in. So we have set cost reduction and productivity targets that span all of those cost categories. In some cases, that does put pressure on headcount, and you've seen that. But it's not something where we set a headcount target or apply the same formula everywhere. It's really important that we give our business leaders and functional leaders the flexibility to tailor their cost structure to be competitive. So it's not a one-size-fits-all, and the business dynamics are very different, and different parts of our business is in different sites. So that's important from an overall context standpoint. Now the reductions that we're making in Puget Sound that you've seen in the news, again those are being done within this overall cost reduction effort and also being done in a way that's very mindful and respectful of our employees. We're starting first, as you noted, with the voluntary layoff packages and/or attrition. I think it's a good reminder that in a company of about 160,000 people, normal annual attrition is about 4% to 5%, just when you look at the workforce demographics. So that alone provides us some flexibility on how we can make headcount reduction and do it in a way that's mindful and respectful of our employees. And so that's where we start. In some cases, we have had had to do involuntary layoffs, but that tends to be on the margins and done very selectively, where we don't have other options. So that's our game plan going forward. I won't give you any specific headcount targets because that's not the way we do our business. We set cost reduction productivity targets. We look at all elements for our cost structure. And if comes down to direct headcount, we deal with that in a way that's very respectful of our employees and trying to do our best to help them transition when that does become a necessity.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jon Ostrower with the Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jon Ostrower with the Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on sort of the strategic future of how you account for everything at Boeing. You've told your investors over the last 5 years or longer to really focus on cash, not earnings, as you go through the 787 process. But certainly, the windfall t
componenttext: Just a question on sort of the strategic future of how you account for everything at Boeing. You've told your investors over the last 5 years or longer to really focus on cash, not earnings, as you go through the 787 process. But certainly, the windfall that they expect clearly anchors a lot of their expectations for what they see the future of Boeing. So you've got this nascent SEC probe on the projections for 787. You've got downgrades that are causing volatility in your share prices as a result of those projections. I just want to ask, is program accounting still the right model for Boeing? Airbus used IFRS. Bombardier and Embraer and analysts tend to expect a certain level of volatility in the cash that comes in during the development program. Is it still right for Boeing when you look at all that's transpired in the last few months?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, John, I would say our accounting is compliant with GAAP. That's first and foremost, all right? And that's what it is. And obviously, Airbus is in a different accounting standards, and offsets adhering to that one. So we are -- that's our focus. That
componenttext: Well, John, I would say our accounting is compliant with GAAP. That's first and foremost, all right? And that's what it is. And obviously, Airbus is in a different accounting standards, and offsets adhering to that one. So we are -- that's our focus. That's our priority, and that's how we account for everything we do within the business. As far as focus on cash, I think just like any business, it's about the bottom line at the end of the day no matter what accounting standards you're under. It's about how efficient you are with your cash and how effective you are with managing that and deploying it. So I wouldn't view our focus on cash, frankly, any different from any other business. At the end of the day, it's all about what's left over. And what your costs were in and what you sold your product for and then what you do with it. And we're trying to keep it simple in that regard because ultimately we want to reinvest in the future and we want to return cash to those that are putting their trust in us through the shareholder base and invest in our people. And that's the priorities.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with the Seattle Times.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with the Seattle Times.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things I'd like to ask about. First of all, just following up on the Puget Sound headcount question. Boeing has projected that by midyear you'll have managed through attrition and voluntary buyouts to lower headcount by about 4,000. Do you anticipate
componenttext: Two things I'd like to ask about. First of all, just following up on the Puget Sound headcount question. Boeing has projected that by midyear you'll have managed through attrition and voluntary buyouts to lower headcount by about 4,000. Do you anticipate that you'll need more than that in the second half of the year? And then second question, so -- you're pushed to get more out of the aftermarket and services. That's been talked about by Boeing for years and years and years. What's different now? What -- how are you going about it more aggressively? John [indiscernible] mentioned a change in what you're doing with spirit. Are you taking -- actively taking steps that are different to take those services back? Headcount first, though.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Dominic, let me field both of those. First of all, on headcount. As I said earlier, we have set some aggressive cost and cost reduction productivity targets for the year that are aligned with our overall business strategy. And we are looking at all
componenttext: Okay. Dominic, let me field both of those. First of all, on headcount. As I said earlier, we have set some aggressive cost and cost reduction productivity targets for the year that are aligned with our overall business strategy. And we are looking at all categories of costs. And that includes beyond headcount both in our internal indirect costs as well as in our supply chain. And I think it's important that we continue to keep that in mind. Our direct headcount is one important category but not the only one. And our business leaders are looking across all of those cost categories. I will say the overall macro trend that we have for this year is that we expect employment will be net down moderately. I can't give you a specific number there, but we are on a moderate downward trend enterprise-wide this year as we drive productivity. As I said earlier, we're also doing that trying to be very mindful of our employees. And as you know, we have a great deal of respect for our people. They are world-class. They're the best in the world at what they do. And where we can leverage attrition and the voluntary layoff programs that we put in place, we will. And so far, that approach has been very effective for us, and I think that's good for the business and good for our people. Ultimately, good for our customers. So that's our headset on that approach. On your second question about services, you're right. It's something that we have talked about for some time. I can tell you that we are very serious about growing our services business. So as we laid in our strategy for the next planning cycle, and more broadly for the next decade, that is one of our focused growth areas. The market is large. As I said, about $4 trillion over the next 20 years. We have market share room to grow. But again, I want to emphasize that we are growing services in a growing marketplace. This is not about taking share from others or dividing up a fixed pie. This is clearly a growing marketplace. And with the right kind of business model, this can be good for industry and our customers. We are taking very specific actions on that. Our services business leaders, Stan Deal and Ed DeLansky, are teamed up. I think our One Boeing approach, where we work across commercial and defense globally, is a differentiator for us. In some cases, we are looking at specific parts inside of our aircraft, as you've seen in the [indiscernible] where our unique OEM knowledge, we think, can provide value for our customers. In some cases, we're pursuing modification and upgrade businesses. The 737 freighter conversion program, I think, is a good, specific example there. And then some of the work we're doing in information-based services, like GoldCare and performance-based logistics. Those are specific things that we're doing. So it is a focused, high-priority strategy. And we have actions underway to support that strategy.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will be from Alwyn Scott with Reuters.
componenttext: And that will be from Alwyn Scott with Reuters.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also on the productivity question. How worried are you about the significant change in the value of the dollar and the competitive edge that, that potentially gives to Airbus in coming years? And to what extent is that factoring into your cost containment
componenttext: Also on the productivity question. How worried are you about the significant change in the value of the dollar and the competitive edge that, that potentially gives to Airbus in coming years? And to what extent is that factoring into your cost containment and productivity efforts, cutting jobs and cutting other costs even as you produce more than ever?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, certainly, it's a factor as we think about competing. And it goes really to just the broader objective that Dennis outlined on competing in the marketplace to win. No matter what -- whether it's exchange rates or whether the competition being more
componenttext: I mean, certainly, it's a factor as we think about competing. And it goes really to just the broader objective that Dennis outlined on competing in the marketplace to win. No matter what -- whether it's exchange rates or whether the competition being more efficient or inefficient, it's all about competing in the marketplace. And then as we discussed, being able to invest going forward and then rewarding all the stakeholders that put their trust in us. That's fundamentally what's behind us. But if exchange rates are going to move around for over time, we don't rely on exchange rates. But the fact is, they're sometimes an advantage sometimes disadvantage, and that have the flexibility in our enterprise we're able to compete, and a matter what. That exchange rate is in that sense that we have at the team and that's the focus it's good to take place -- continue to take place going forward.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
